awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Exploring Unknown Diversity of Short Peptide Neurotoxins and Prey Targets of Provisioning Spider Wasps (Pompilidae) of New Mexico
awd_abstract_narration:
Biologists and chemists from the Department of Natural Sciences at Western New Mexico University will collaborate on an investigation of the molecular interactions between predatory spider wasps (family Pompilidae) and the spiders they sting and paralyze to use as living food provisions for their own parasitic larvae.  Beyond gathering data that will describe the biology and evolutionary history of this particular system, the project also addresses key questions about molecular adaptation, the molecular physiology of predator/prey and parasite/host interactions, and the mechanisms that help generate biodiversity - such as antagonistic coevolution.  About 200 species of spider wasps are known to occur in the United States.  The venoms of these solitary insects are known to be relatively simple, consisting mainly of short peptides such as pompilidotoxins (PMTXs). PMTXs are neurotoxins that bind to a known site on voltage-gated sodium channel proteins, inhibiting their inactivation and disrupting the functions of the nervous system.  This project will characterize venom peptides from a diverse sample of spider wasps using mass spectrometry and venom gland transcriptome sequencing; and examine the DNA sequence diversity of targeted spider sodium channels, particularly at sites critical for PMTX binding.  Since survival and reproduction of spider wasps depends on the potency of their venoms, while survival and reproduction of targeted spiders depends on their genetic sensitivity (or possible resistance) to the toxins, this project will also use phylogenetic trees of species relationships to describe the evolutionary histories of these molecules and their interactions, which are likely to evolve via natural selection.  

Animal neurotoxins are of broad interest due to their potential medical value in treating human health conditions including pain, epilepsy, stroke, and some cardiovascular disorders.  Additionally, seminal discoveries in neuroscience emerged from structure/function studies of nervous system proteins such as sodium channels, and how they are affected by natural neurotoxins.  For the grantee institution, this project will enhance research infrastructure via partial funding for shared-use molecular biology instrumentation and provide new opportunities for undergraduate participants to gain experience and training in research techniques used in molecular biology and analytical chemistry.  Data generated by the project will be deposited into public databases including NCBI/GenBank, UniProt, and PRIDE (EMBL-EBI).  Voucher specimens used in the characterizations of wasp venoms and spider sodium channels will be deposited into the permanent collections of the Gila Center for Natural History at Western New Mexico University in Silver City, NM.

por.por_cntn:
This project -- conducted at a small, primarily undergraduate institution -- focused on evolutionary adaptations in an ion channel protein (the voltage-gated sodium channel) that is critical to the functioning of the nervous system and muscle in nearly all animals including humans.  Many venomous animals subdue their prey by utilizing neurotoxins that bind directly to the sodium channel, causing prey paralysis.  We hypothesized that a molecular evolutionary arms race has driven the evolution of prey choice in spider-wasps (Pompilidae), a family of wasps in which some species are generalists and utilize diverse prey spiders, while others are specialists and target only specific kinds of spiders.  We hypothesized that on one hand, Darwinian natural selection would favor the evolution of novel mutations in the sodium channels of prey spiders that provide physiological resistance to the effects of wasp toxin;  while on the other hand, wasps would evolve more potent venom toxins over time, and a tendency to specialize upon spiders that lack these mutations and are thus more susceptible to wasp venom.  The results of our research support all of these hypotheses.

The key findings of our research were as follows:  

1) Mapping known prey preferences onto a phylogenetic tree of spider-wasps indicated that Pompilidae were ancestrally generalist predators, and that prey specialization upon specific spiders evolved several times independently in multiple wasp lineages.  

2) At least two types of wasp venom toxins, alpha- and beta-pompilidotoxin, seem to have already been present in the early shared ancestor of all spider-wasps.  We isolated both of these pompilidotoxins from the wasp Hemipepsis, but prior to our research they were not known to co-occur in any wasp species.  

 3) We discovered multiple independent evolutionary origins of two novel, previously undescribed mutations in spider sodium channels (at sites 1609 and 1616 of receptor site-3) that we hypothesized would make those sodium channels less vulnerable (and partly resistant) to pompilidotoxins.  

4) When ancestrally generalist wasps evolved shifts toward prey specialization, they tended to go after spiders that did not possess those novel mutations, and we hypothesized that this was because those spider mutations are resistant to pompilidotoxins .

5) When we subjected the novel mutations we discovered to experimental tests -- by expressing them in living cells and exposing them to alpha- and beta-pompilidotoxins using a method known as voltage clamp -- we found that these mutations at sites 1609 and 1616 are indeed resistant to both alpha- and beta-pompilidotoxin.  Intriguingly, the novel mutations appear to be more resistant to the more potent wasp toxin (beta-pompilidotoxin).  All of these findings, we conclude, are indicative of a molecular evolutionary arms race that has shaped prey choice in spider-wasps, as well as the spider sodium channels themselves.

The impacts of this project went well beyond these questions regarding the evolution of wasps and spiders.  Discovering new sodium channel variants in nature, and confirming experimentally that they have unique properties (such as toxin resistance), is a common pathway through which neuroscientists have historically approached studies on the relationship between ion channel structure and function.  The project was also beneficial in many ways to a small, primarily undergraduate institution that typically is unable to conduct research of this type due to lack of resources.  For example, the project equipped and funded the construction of the first shared-use molecular biology research laboratory at the university, that is now used by undergraduate and faculty researchers for diverse research projects unrelated to this award.  More than fifteen science undergraduates learned molecular research skills by participating in this project over the term of the award, and more than a third of them went on to pursue PhD studies elsewhere in Biology or Chemistry.  These students, the PI, and several collaborating scientists presented this research at both US-based and international scientific conferences; integrated the content into several university courses; and experienced the professional growth that came with pursuing an original research project at a small undergraduate university where such research would have been impossible without an award of this type.
